text: Bonjour Lomond we're marking alex the
vagabrothers and this is our week in
Paris
Paris the most fabled European city is
also the most touristic it's a challenge
any traveler who wants to live like a
local because we have so many
preconceptions about what Paris really
is for most this is the image of Paris
the Eiffel Tower don't you dump the send
stylish people drinking cafe au lait at
street side coffee shops cheesy
accordion music setting the mood but
that's not all Paris is it's a vibrant
city that most of us miss because we're
too busy doing what we think we're
supposed to do
visiting the sights playing the charades
and perpetuating the myth so as we sped
up the coast from San Sebastian we were
determined to spend our week in Paris
not seeing the sights but meeting the
people who live here luckily for us my
friend from university Erika is a chef
here in Paris and she offered to let us
stay in her apartment in the 20th along
a small which is a residential area with
few tourist attractions this is probably
the quintessential Parisian experience
since all dibs overlooking z-ray is it
world let's just eat it drop the French
acronym sorry it was a great place to
see how people live and soak up the
Parisian pace of life and no we didn't
see anybody wearing a brain Alex and I
are big fans of couchsurfing and staying
with a local makes an important change
you're one step closer to Breezy in life
and suddenly you're plugged into their
social scene you ready to go explore the
city case in point
on our first night in town Erika took us
to a house party where we made some new
friends and assaulted them with our
horrible French it wasn't something we
could find in a guidebook but it was a
great experience that we never could
have plan
the next morning we woke up hungry
France and food go together like wine
and cheese and Paris is the capital of
it all we wanted to eat Paris but we
want to do it right so we met with local
YouTube chef Alex from French guy
cooking
welcome to show us places we could never
find on our own Alex showed us around
the city by bicycle we had breakfast in
a cafe
lunch in a browser and dinner in Little
Saigon afterwards we had the most French
dessert possible wine attention if you
haven't seen that video you check it out
right here and you should because outs
the hilarious and talented chef who
taught us a lot about Paris I can teach
you a hell of a lot about French cuisine
but no one is better at introducing
travelers to locals than Jim Haynes
an American expat writer traveler who's
lived in Paris since the 1970s and been
hosting open Sunday dinner parties every
week for the last 30 years it's the best
open secret in Paris everyone's invited
all you have to do is RSVP on his
website and give what you can to order
to dinner
more details below in the info box it's
really cool at 8:00 p.m. his Atelier
fills up with people from around the
world it's a great time to be here all
of whom share a common goal to eat meat
and enjoy each other's company well my
name is Jim Haines and from Louisiana
that lived in South America Scotland
London Amsterdam Paris longest of my
life has been Paris about 36 years ago
by pure chance a dancer stayed here
whose hobby was cooking proposed us
cooking the Okla me until my friend
a lot of friends and the first dinner
was 25 people every one of them late
that night that don't let her go home
keep her she then proposed to do a
dinner and Wednesday and Saturday as
long as she was a houseguest and
fortunately for me she married a
Frenchman and she's still here and she
still cooks 36 years later that was just
a little taste of Jim's ideas but we're
posting a full interview soon so stay
tuned for that one hopefully the video
inspired you to visit this city a little
bit differently the next time you come
let us know what you think in the
comment box below or by tweeting us at
Burger brothers as always if you enjoy
the video give it a thumbs up share it
with your friends and subscribe to our
channel for new travel videos every
